questions.question: Is supper ready ...............................?
questions.description: In questions yet is used to ask whether something expected has happened.

questions.question: I have .................................. to hear from them.
questions.description: Yet is used before a to-infinitive to suggest that something has not happened.

questions.question: They have ..................................... made an offer.
questions.description: Already refers to the present or past. It is used to suggest that something happened sooner than expected.

questions.question: She has ................................. to start working on the new project.
questions.description: Yet is used before a to-infinitive to suggest that something has not happened.

questions.question: They are ................................ waiting.
questions.description: Still is used to say that something is in the present and it has not finished.

questions.question: The university is ...................................... to publish the results.
questions.description: Yet is used before a to-infinitive to suggest that something has not happened.

questions.question: It is ................................... raining.
questions.description: Still is used to say that something is in the present and it has not finished.

questions.question: The postman has ..................................... been.
questions.description: Already refers to the present or past. It is used to suggest that something happened sooner than expected.

questions.question: Has the postman come ........................................?
questions.description: In questions yet is used to ask whether something expected has happened.

questions.question: The families of the victims are .................................... to get justice.
questions.description: Yet is used before a to-infinitive to suggest that something expected has not happened.
